California is a large state.\n\nIn large SoCal cities like Los Angeles and San Diego, you can find good, reasonably priced Mexican restaurants in almost any neighborhood that has a large Mexican-American population. My rule of thumb for selecting Mexican restaurants is that if I\u2019m the only white person in the place, the food is likely to be both authentic and tasty. (Yes, I realize that\u2019s a little racist. It\u2019s still true.)\n\nIn cities with large immigrant populations from East Asia or the Middle East, you can find good, reasonably priced restaurants in almost any ethnic neighborhood. Look for little hole-in-the-wall places that cater to customers who want their ethnic food to be authentic.\n\nDon\u2019t worry about the restaurant\u2019s d\u00e9cor or whether it\u2019s located in a strip mall. Some of the best restaurants have the cheapest decorations. [{\\\"spans\\\": [{\\\"text\\\": \\\"There are so many authentic Korean restaurants in OC. The best are in Buena Park and Garden Grove. There are many Korean BBQ all you can eat restaurants that do not serve the best cuts of meats but they are pretty darned good anyway. But the best premium Korean BBQ is Mo Ran Gak in Garden Grove and Kung Ho Dong Baekjeoung BBQ in Buena Park and Irvine. The best Galbi Tang and Sol lung Tang beef soups are at Han Yang in BP. For Sundubu (tofu stew) I recommend Kaju Soft Tofu in Garden Grove and BCD in several locations is a close second place. For authentic spicy pork stew go to Gam Ja Tang House in Garden Grove. These places are not just good, they are fabulous and very very popular. I do not recommend going at peak times unless you want to wait an hour or longer. If you decide to wait I will assure you it is worth it. (These restaurants are on a par with the best in Los Angeles Koreatown and only a notch below restaurants in Seoul. I\\\\u2019m not one who frequents fancy restaurants these days, so I\\\\u2019ll opt for a more boring answer and stick to casual regional chains. Best sandwiches: Sourdough and Company, with multiple locations throughout the Sacramento region. Best family restaurant: Black Bear Diner, located throughout California, especially Northern California. They pretty much killed off Marie Callendar\\\\u2019s and Coco\\\\u2019s, but I forgive them because their food is better. Best fast-food burger: Habit. Located statewide. Yes, they\\\\u2019re better than In and Out. Best fish tacos: California Fish Grill, started in SoCal but coming into the NorCal scene. Sorry Rubio\\\\u2019s, you\\\\u2019re outmatched. Best pizza: we\\\\u2019re not really known for good pizza, but the two best I\\\\u2019ve experienced are Chicago Fire and Old Town Pizza, each with several locations around the Sacramento area. Best Italian: Mario\\\\u2019s Italian Cafe, located throughout the Coachella Valley. Best Mexican: no chains are worthy of this category. Instead, just look for a place that says \\\\u201ctaqueria y carniceria\\\\u201d. A carniceria is a butcher shop. If they\\\\u2019ve got a butcher shop and a Mexican market, then dude they\\\\u2019re gonna know what they\\\\u2019re doing. Best Asian: again not a chain. [{\\\"spans\\\": [{\\\"text\\\": \\\"I\\\\u2019m not a good one to ask this question. You might think so, since I was born and raised in the OC (except for the 15-yr birdwalk to Alaska). All you professional chefs out there\\\\u2026don\\\\u2019t be hating on me for this, but I think the food in Orange County sucks! It only takes one trip to France or even just to Northern California to get the full impact of how inferior our restaurant food is in Orange County. Oh I know there are places rated 5-star\\\\u2026compared to what? Other restaurants in OC? So they\\\\u2019re comparing mediocre to mediocre? Not good enough, folks. Our food lacks freshness, creativity, and passion. I\\\\u2019ve eaten better food at small, counter service joints in Berkeley that are better than anything OC has to offer. Freshness you can taste. Anchorage, Alaska, has the best seafood I\\\\u2019ve ever eaten anywhere. And all over France you can eat most anything that was picked out of the garden right before it was served on your plate. What they can do with sauces, is almost a religious experience, gastronomically speaking. Unpasteurized dairy products really do taste differently. You can taste the passion in their food.\\\", \\\"modifiers\\\": {}}], \\\"indent\\\": 0, \\\"quoted\\\": false, \\\"type\\\": \\\"plain\\\", \\\"is_rtl\\\": false}, {\\\"spans\\\": [{\\\"text\\\": \\\"No matter where your favorite eating establishment is in Orange County, it is woefully lacking in simple sophistication. The waitresses wear these cute Scottish lass type outfits.  It's been open since the 1920s and it was one of Walt Disney's regular hang outs when he used to work at his nearby studio.\\\", \\\"modifiers\\\": {}}], \\\"indent\\\": 0, \\\"quoted\\\": false, \\\"type\\\": \\\"plain\\\", \\\"is_rtl\\\": false}, {\\\"spans\\\": [{\\\"text\\\": \\\"And Dan Tana's in West Hollywood--I will add this one here, too: I love their marinara sauce that they use on various dishes and the people watching, there can be interesting.\\\", \\\"modifiers\\\": {}}], \\\"indent\\\": 0, \\\"quoted\\\": false, \\\"type\\\": \\\"plain\\\", \\\"is_rtl\\\": false}, {\\\"spans\\\": [{\\\"text\\\": \\\"Japanese:\\\", \\\"modifiers\\\": {\\\"bold\\\": true}}, {\\\"text\\\": \\\"\\\\nKush in Echo Park. (I have lucked out and found tables available there, but it can get filled up quickly.)\\\", \\\"modifiers\\\": {}}], \\\"indent\\\": 0, \\\"quoted\\\": false, \\\"type\\\": \\\"plain\\\", \\\"is_rtl\\\": false}, {\\\"spans\\\": [{\\\"text\\\": \\\"Ebizu Tavern in Little Tokyo.  They offer sushi as well as a HUGE menu of various regional Japanese items.  Perhaps the big menu could be a turn off to some people, but they do offer many items that other restaurants don't.  I've been there many times and will often try something new--and enjoy it--every visit.  Great Happy Hour specials, too.  (They have a daytime and late night Happy Hour.)  I often go there with Japanese friends who love it, too.
